Certainly! Here is an example of a revised non-deterministic matrix:

Example:

* $X = {1, 2, 3}$
* $Y = {2, 3}$
* $V = {\text{p}, \text{q}}$
* $C = {\neg, \text{and}}$
* $arity(\neg) = 1$
* $arity(\text{and}) = 2$
* $\cdot(\neg, 1) = {2, 3}$
* $\cdot(\neg, 2) = {1, 3}$
* $\cdot(\neg, 3) = {1, 2}$
* $\cdot(\text{and}, 1, 1) = {1}$
* $\cdot(\text{and}, 1, 2) = {1}$
* $\cdot(\text{and}, 1, 3) = {1}$
* $\cdot(\text{and}, 2, 2) = {2}$
* $\cdot(\text{and}, 2, 3) = {2}$
* $\cdot(\text{and}, 3, 3) = {3}$
* $\cdot(\text{and}, 2, 1) = {1, 2}$
* $\cdot(\text{and}, 3, 1) = {1, 3}$
* $\cdot(\text{and}, 3, 2) = {2, 3}$

In this revised non-deterministic matrix, the negation connective has a truth-value of 2 or 3 when applied to the truth-value 1, and a truth-value of 1, 2, or 3 when applied to the truth-values 2 or 3. The "and" connective has a truth-value of 1 when applied to the truth-values 1 and 1, and a truth-value of 2 or 3 when applied to the truth-values 2 and 2 or 3
